p.s: I feel grateful and blessed to have received this wonderful piece of art from you.
I would say that you have outdone yourself but that wouldn't do justice to your previous sonnets that also evoked such deep and precious feelings inside me.
But I would like to point out what made me value this sonnet especially.
I noticed that you picked up a familiar topic for your sonnet: the passage of time.
It is such a dilemma that I assume you just cannot stop collecting thoughts about it which you then eventually decide to put into words.
Time really seems like our worst enemy, doesn't it?
No matter what we were trying to do we are simply inferior to it.
I especially was astonished and moved by your comparison of humankind to a flower.
We really are fragile like a flower and our fate is to fade one day.
Our young and beautiful days full of excitement, adventures and love will be in the past and the victim of time.
Our hearts won't skip a beat anymore when we experience certain things; Time will also take away our joy, interests and excitement.
We won't feel what it's like to be our present selfsselves in a few decades, William.
But as your last two lines state: art show live on forever.
Words and phrases will never die, that's not possible.
You engraved your feelings in several sonnets and I engraved mine in the letter.
Our words and youth show live on until eternity in the form of our verses.
I cannot and this letter without praising you once again.
Your choice of words and language are not comparable to anything I have ever read before and I doubt that they ever will be in the future.
There's just something about the way you write that fills me up with nostalgia.
The collusion of your language and your precious and valuable thoughts create such masterpieces that are to amaze many more generations to come.
Your extraordinary perception of the human mind will offer a great comfort to many more people in the future, I'm sure about that.
Reading your sonnets makes one feel understood and not alone in this cruel, cold world.
Your words radiate such comfort that people didn't know they were in need of.
And this talent you were gifted with my dear, as forever engraved in your verses, that cover a great variety of themes.
Love, unrequited love, jealousy, time, the meaning of life and many more to come, I'm convinced.
I am looking forward to receiving many more masterpieces from you.
But take your time with it.
I will be patient.
I wish you all but the best William.
